content:
Posted: April 20, 2014
												Now, when I first downloaded this, as it was during the free weekend, I believed it would be an excellent strategy game. I was wrong. Now, the concept seems great, but just too poorly excecuted for me to like it.1. AI- Well, 1 shot can kill a man, but unfortunately, sometimes when I give orders to my characters, and press to see them, they don't do it. All i can say is thank god for the planning phase, or else the mission would be over before i could say "WHAT THE ****?!" Your friendly AI, the people you control, take like 3 seconds to fire, keep in mind most turns only last like 5 seconds, this gives you around 2 seconds to move a guy.2. Graphics- So-so, is all i can say, only about 2 death animations when a dude is shot, and most of the detail obviosly went into the pictures of characters, and that isn't saying much.3. Story- Don't even bother, try to understand, your brain will disolve, but not before giving you the finger as it turns to mush.4 -Gameplay- Oh boy, is this difficult. NO DIFFICULTY SETTING, except for the type of AI in instant skirmish (suicidal, old etc)1 shot=1 kill regardless. You can get hit from the other side of the room with a single shotgun pellet and still die. Yeah programmers, Health bars would be nice seeing as your dumb squad fail to shoot unless they get a bullet in the face. Also, what the game does not tell you is that once you press "PRIME", enemies will move, which completely buggers any plan you made. All you can do is hope they do not turn around when your guy is ready to shoot them. Trust me, most of the time they walk off, see one of my guys about to kill another Enyo:Nomad or whatever the **** they're called, and boom, you're dead. No buts, just dead *heavy "yells DED, not big suprise"*. Why could we not see where enemies go in the form of waypoints, fewer of these waypoints or where they face the harder the difficulty, where a DIFFICULTY SETTING WOULD BE NICE.5. Soundtrack- Best part about the game, not Portal 2 level, but still good.6. Humor- Only in achivement names bub, otherwise, you need to only play the tutorial for a sarcastic remark.Overall, unless it's on sale for around £3 (about 5 dollars if you're American) I'd stay away. For £18.99, I could just go save up about £2 more and buy BOTH Portal games or Half Life/ hl2, so if they think they can charge more for this game alone. I don't think this is right.However, if you are still here and not up in arms either at the game or at me, THIS IS MY OPINION. Personally, I don't like this game, but if you do, that's fine. I just want to warn people about the problems I have with this game.On that note, goodbye, I am off the play some (in my opinion) better games.

content:
Posted: April 18, 2014
												[5/10]I want to like this game. I really do. It gives me nostalgia for Laser Squad Nemesis. FS is the love-child of LSN and Tron, but it doesn'y do either justice. The campaign is repetetive. The environment the game projects may follow the story, but it is extremely uninteresting and dissatisfying. The maps in multiplayer are not symmetrical, and both teams get different troop count and type, so it isn't even fair. All in all, a poorly executed attempt to replicate the success of Laser Squad Nemesis.

number of helpful: 1 of 5 people (20%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 4, 2014
												I really wanted to like this game, but there is just so much wrong with it. I was told by several people that it is "Rainbow six planing mode the game" this couldnt be further from the thruth and that has nothing to do with the cyberpunk setting.The setting is actually really nice and the charecters are entertaining. There are however several big gameplay problems.1.The mission start. You always get a group of several soldiers. You can not place them in starting zones, which is fine. The problem is instead they are placed randomly around the map. Add to this that the enemies are placed at random as well and what you get is an unbalanceable game. You will play one mission that is just not possible and when you restart the very same mission it will be unbelievably easy because by chance the soldiers were placed in your favour.2.The weapons. RPGs and grenadelaunchers are a lot of fun. The Shotgun is believeable to even though its a bit shortranged. Apart from that the weapons are a mess. First of all there is a "Machinegun" yet soldiers cant lie down. So they spray at each other from about 20 meters till one hits the other. The enviroments are all about 50m x 50m why not implement a Machinepistol instead? Next up the Sniper. Yeah tiny enviromens + a sniperrifle how is this♥♥♥♥♥♥supposed to work? Why not a rifleman instead with an assault rifle? 3.Hit prediction. You have the option the precalculate your next move. The only downside is you have to guess yourself what the enemy will do. The AI is utter rubish so you will have to make a few wild guesses, but even when you guess right and everything plans out like you wanted it to .... you are still going  to loose at least one soldier. Why? Because that guy you shot in the back in the calculation before he has time to turn around will in reality be a lot quicker than your guy turn around and shoot him, for no logical reason. It makes the whole precalculate option pretty pointless.

												Cool idea, but sometimes the mechanics just don't make sense. i.e: Cannot shoot from cover (peeking out) and aiming down sights and rounding a corner doesn't provide the suprise attack that you would think it would. Also...on mac OSX...WHY CAN'T I TAB OUT from fullscreen...seriously developers...its not hard...literally all my other games work just fine. 5/10

content:
Posted: June 25, 2014
												Not really sure why this game rates as well as it does with reviewers.It feels slow and random. It's bound to be slow because of the turn based nature, but add on the amount of time it takes to compute a turn (a surprisingly long time!), and .. it's a bit boring.Now factor in that where your team are randomly plopped on the map basically defines if you will win or not. Bad placement? Then you dont really stand a chance. Woo game of skill.Oh and the weapon types don't feel balanced either. Shotguns being basically useless unless you can get close to someone without being shot. See "placement" above.Soooo .. it's slow, even more slow than a usual turn based game, feels random and unbalanced. Yet gets some really good reviews. I get the feeling a lot of reviewers just play a game for 20 mins, and then write a nice review so they get more free games sent to them, coz this one's a bit crap.

content:
Posted: September 3, 2011
												Turn based grid-less version of X-COM but without the resource management and metagame. The most interesting part is planning out both your moves and predicting your enemy's moves, playing it out, and optimizing your turn based on your available information and predictions. LoS and cover can be frustrating with you occasionally you being shot before you can shoot the enemy without explanation from the game. Single player is pretty generic and multiplayer is a bit empty. I assume most people set up their own matches between friends because I get the feeling this is one of those games that a dozen hardcore people play publicly just to stomp people online.This could be a great tactical play-by-email game between friends but I wouldn't recommend it unless your friends get it or you buy multiple copies for some. Be prepared for 30min-1hr long turns and week long games; this is something you really have to dig deep into.

number of helpful: 0 of 3 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 10, 2015
												Between countless Fire Emblem games, some tabletop roleplaying, and a recent campaign of XCOM: Enemy Unknown, I've come to enjoy turn-based strategy. There's something very satisfying about using your brain to look at the situation, and by taking careful risks, use each and every single one of your units to make a satisfying move which puts you further towards winning the game.That was what I was hoping for when I bought Frozen Synapse - a nice, fun, turn-based strategy which lets me plan carefully in order to win. Personally, I was almost crossing my fingers for an XCOM/Fire Emblem rip-off, since to me, they represent the core ideas and mechanics of turn-based strategy and more of that sort of gameplay couldn't be a bad thing.Unfortunately, what I found instead was a boring, drab game where the "strategy" comes down to "have you guessed what your opponents were going to do?" Sure, that's an essential part of most strategy games, but usually you get help, like showing where your opponents can move, or knowing how much damage they'll do so you'll know which units can survive a fight with them. Instead, in Frozen Synapse, you choose which actions you want your units to take, press the button to end your turn, and then your opponents make all of their moves at the same time.Whilst this doesn't sound like a bad thing, it means that you can spend time setting up your units, planning for your opponents to do something, only for them to bypass that method completely and catch you by surprise, all because you didn't have the precognition to see into the future and realise that they could do that. Sure, you could try and plan for all outcomes, but that means using more units and therefore cutting off your options elsewhere. Essentially, gameplay boils down to you crossing your fingers that the enemy walks in front of your units and dies before they notice your units.On top of all that, the controls are confusing as all hell and very unintuitive. There's a tutorial, but it rushes by pretty quickly and being given step-by-step instructions is much different to having to think ahead and choose and work out what to do in a real level. I should say something about the graphics and story too, but really, what is there to say? The graphics are ugly, uninspired, and boring, and the story is a bunch of cyberpunk technobabble which made my eyes immediately glaze over because it was so boring.Normally, I try and finish games to the end because I want to get my money's worth, but this is the first time in a very long while that I've simply quit and said "No." I tried to get into the game and give it a good go, but as I struggled to predict the enemies' paths for the umpteenth time, I recalled that in video games, players should be interested within five to fifteen minutes. Well, I gave the game nearly an hour of my time, and as far as I'm concerned, I shouldn't have gone further than fifteen minutes.Overall, I would not recommend Frozen Synapse. This is not the type of turn-based strategy I enjoy, and whilst it's certainly a nice try and something different, there's a reason that turn-by-turn strategy has remained dominant in many games - for example, chess - for so long: because it works and it's fun, unlike Frozen Synapse.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												I love a good strategy game, but I could not get into this one.  Every little step requires absolute micromanagement.  Yes, that does allow for greater precision, but it also quickly becomes overwhelmingly tedious.The flavorless presentation doesn't help either.  It's visually bland, the level and characters all in one of three solid, textureless colors.  This attempted minimalism only makes the world feel lifeless.  The story is equally lacking in both color and texture, and is easily forgettable.There's countless strategy games out there--many of them far more worth your time than this one.  Go play XCOM instead.

number of helpful: 8 of 20 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 24, 2014
												 I really wanted to like Frozen Synapse but it just didn’t click for me. I thought the combat would be more like X-Com but while similar, it’s different in a bad way. It is still technically turn-based, but instead of each unit getting an individual turn, your whole team has a turn and you assign them moves & tasks, which all get carried out at the same time. The enemy units move all together at the same time your units do, which results in wasted turns & frustration. Let’s say you want to move one unit, who is exposed, behind some cover. You want another unit to camp behind cover & shoot a bad guy as he moves. You have to instruct both of them on what you want them to do, then basically push the “play” button and watch events unfold. Unfortunately, an enemy unit moves into firing range of the guy you told to move into cover. You couldn’t anticipate the enemy would move there, so your guy keeps stupidly running forward as you watch helplessly while the enemy blows him away. Meanwhile, your other unit jumps into a perfect firing position right at the start of the turn, just like you told him. Unfortunately, that other enemy unit went a different way than you thought he was going and basically gets a free movement turn while your guy idiotically sits in one place the entire time. Events like this are commonplace.Maybe it gets better. Maybe I wasn’t doing it right. All I can tell you is that I didn’t enjoy the hour of Frozen Synapse I played. I’ve thought about going back and giving it another shot but then realize I’d have to sit through the entire tutorial again because I don’t remember any of the controls. I have zero desire to do that.

Posted: March 15, 2014
												This has got to be one of the most boring games I have ever played. I know its a game about strategy and its not supposed to be all up in your face with action but its soooo boring. In Frozen Synapse you decide where you want your soldiers to go from a top down angle while the enemy does the same thing. This phase takes way too long and makes you want to play the game less and less. Then you watch it play out. If 2 soldiers from different teams come in contact they will shoot at each other. That is the most fun thing about this game. Yeah...thats it really, and its not even that fun. You just see them shoot at each other and then one of them dies.  I only have 1 hour on this game for a reason, I can't stand it. The gameplay is repetative and boring. I sound like a broken record here so ill just end it. I would give this game a 2/10. If you like watching blue people walk around corners and have long setup times, this game will give you a boner

content:
Posted: October 4, 2014
												Frozen Synapse is a turn based strategy game set in cyber space. It reminded me bit of TRON. It is all about out thinking your opponent whether that is another player or the games AI.The story is captivating however the amount of text to read between each level can get annoying after a while.The graphic are simple but effective. Any detail in graphics look smooth enough.Sound effect are very effective and work well.This game is easy to get into however very difficult to master. Because of this and the amount of text to read, I find it difficult to gather any motivation to play it. It is fun for a day or two but the game play does loose its interest quickly. I am afraid that I cannot recommend this game. There are many others like this which are a lot more fun.

content:
Posted: June 15, 2015
												At $25 for a two-pack, this is a damn good deal.  The game basically plays like a Turn-Based Strategy, except that... well, your turns happen at the same time.  This makes multiplayer both strange and frustrating, yet at the same time very competitive and satisfying... and nothing beats the humiliating moment where your opponent micromanges every aspect of the battle and gets his♥♥♥♥♥wiped off the map in two turns!$25 honestly would be a reasonable price for just one copy of the game.  Its soundtrack, its campaign, its skirmish generator, everything, it's all hundreds of hours of content in a highly innovative and polished product.  The fact that you're getting a gift copy for free to let a friend play against you is just a deal that can't be passed up.For strategy enthusiasts and people just looking for something new, look no further.

number of helpful: 1 of 9 people (11%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 1, 2013
												7/10 FS is a turn-taking strategy game that simulates a SWAT team vs SWAT team kind of combat. "Strategy? Turn taking? Sounds boring.", right? Wrong. This game is actually quite a thrill! When it's your turn, you can issue orders like sprint, walk with weapon ready to fire, crouch behind cover, no engagement, and a many others. You can also move your opponents units to predict how they will move. When you think you're happy, you can hit a "test" button to see how it works out then either keep tweeking or commit to your orders. The replay makes every win rewarding. I can't finish campaign, though. Invisible rocket troops isn't my idea of "tactics" or "challenge". The A.I. can be a bit too psychic as well. This makes for a needlessly-impossible combo. It loses points for forcing you to buy 2 copies, making this too expensive for what you get. If FS is on sale, definately try it out. Demo is available too.

content:
Posted: October 16, 2014
												Frozen Synapse is a turn based squad tactics game set in a confuseing scify distopiea utopiea where digimon have guns.  The game has a terrible habit of not telling you things you think you should probably know like that units cannot shoot while ducking behind cover, shotguns not being able to engage hostiles that are more than a rooms width away, and what the hell a "check" command is.  other than that the game just seems flat out unpolished with poor AI.  Sometimes units will try to engage an enemy with their gun clipping through the corner of a wall.  He will then empty his gun into the wall he was hideing behind until he is killed by the enemy he was apparently engageing because your guy was still half exposed.  Sometimes your shotgun unit will just stand infront of an enemy and recive a load of lead to his face because no one told you he wont even ATTEMPT to shoot people that are litteraly only farther than a small rooms width away. this is very confuseing because shotgun projectiles seem to travel the entire map with no problem.  Units also cannot climb through windows or over low obstacles, leaving very little real tactics you can actually employ while entering a building.  The game is also all on one plane, meaning that you cannot climb onto roofs or down into ditches, basements, ECT.  Making all the maps just feel the same...  The asthetic of the game is simple computery blue wireframe untextured simulation which Is alright for this type of game I suppose, but the world just feels empty with no doors to breach or any furniture at all in the buildings.  Yes I know that you are fighting in the digital world net thing, but I would think that doors would be a nice thing to have in any building.  The gameplay seems solid at first until you realize how shallow it is with the whole lack of doors thing going on along with the lack of being able to climb through windows.  On the story side of things, you get mountains and mountains of text and exposition with what I would guess would be a gripping story.  But with SO MUCH UNEXPLAINED JARGON in the lore and no voice acting whatsoever... it all just becomes skippable seeing that you wont be able to understand half the things the characters are talking about anyway.  The only thing done right in this game is the sound track which if you are a fan of electronic music I would suggest buying.  In the end, Frozen Synapes gets dragged down by poor AI, Shallow gameplay, and a boring story.

Posted: August 1, 2013
												One of the Best Asynchronous Turnbased Strategy Games i know.Each player plots his turn, and selects which actions his units are gonna take. And once both players decide to submit the decisions, the game will plot out the plan. This may sound very vague but due to the ability to simulate any possible order the opponent may give his units, it quickly comes down to mind games. While there is a Single Player mode i can not recommend it past learning the game. Your mileage may vary but i did not like the campain, even though the story was quite interesting.

Posted: March 4, 2013
												Set in the far future, Frozen Synapse places you in the role of a tactican who's tasked with giving orders to bio organic robot soldiers called Shapeforms on a mission to help a resistance group, Petrov's Shard, take down a corporation called Enyo:Nomad who are ruling the city of Markov Geist with an iron fist, you will learn more about the world of Frozen Synapse through the files you can review prior to a mission as well as listening to the conversations between the characters, some are even sentient AIs.The game plays out like a turn based strategy game, except it allows you to run simulations of what the enemies might do, but it may very likely not end up being as the simulation predicted and you have to gamble if you're willing to take the risk or just rethink everything.

Posted: June 5, 2014
												Great turn based RTS. I bought it years ago when it was in the humble bundle and I seem to always keep coming back to it.If I could describe it I would say the turns are simultaneous but at the same time asynchronous. Basically you place your moves for your units and hit the calculate outcome button.  Once your opponent has done the same, the computer calculates what the outcome was with those programmed actions.   Makes for a very interesting guessing match of what the opponent will do.  Since it's asynchronous you can carry a game on over a week or finish it in one sitting.  Or like most, have 6 or so games going on at any one time.  Best strategy game I have ever played (well except for chess)!  I wish there were more games like this, I think this is the only one of it’s kind though.

Posted: December 27, 2011
												I really like this game because of its strategic purity.  You can spend as much or as little time with your strategies as you want, and the results pretty directly match your skill and effort.  It's like running your own hand-crafted simulations to outwit your opponent.  Also, the soundtrack is very fitting, which makes it very easy to spend a ton of time planning.

Posted: May 29, 2014
												SummaryIn short, Frozen Synapse is a turn based counter strike with focus on tactics rather than action in a cyper-punk setting.You get thrown right into the action from your first match with little introduction which may put off some people. I did not find it too bad though.When playing against other players online, it feels very rewarding to win a match. Seeing a carefully planned out plan work feels great! However losing also feels as progress as you gain experience points for your actions rather then just the outcome.GameplayYou control a team of units armed with different weapons (either shotgun, grenade, machine-gun, sniper or rocket) in a battlefield against opponent units. Orders are given to a single unit as a path of nodes to travel along and you can assign actions along the path such as "crouch", "ignore at sight",  "shoot at sight", "wait" and "look in this direction". You can order units to take cover, make distractions, flank enemies, flush out enemies and many other tactics that make use of the randomly generated environment. You can also simulate the enemy units to test out your plans and make sure you covered all outcomes. It is hard to describe the feeling of seing enemies fall into your traps or pressured into defeat other than "Just as planned...".The game was slightly intimidating in the beginning as there are many things to get used to and most of it is presented without much introduction. There is a single player campaign which presents all actions from the first mission and the tutorial only teaches a few basic tactics. Generally the overall focus seemed to be on playing online and learning by doing and failing.Multi-playerOnline works overall well. You can play any number of matches you want at once as the game does not progress until both players have submitted your plans. Once both players have submitted their plans, the outcome is played out. You can also choose to have the game notify you by email or through Steam when your next turn is ready.ThemeLastly I really like the overall style of the game. The music is very fitting and the sparse visuals keeps focus on the gameplay.

Posted: June 24, 2014
												This game is just incredible. The design appears simple, but there's so much depth to the strategy that it becomes both addicting and hugely tense in short order. Anticipating enemy movements, adapting to contingencies, and determining the best way to use the forces at your disposal make the gameplay immensely rewarding. The simultaneous turn resolution throws in further decision-making concerns and makes strategy development that much more dynamic and exciting. The soundtrack is phenomenal, as well, and really helps to enhance the cyberpunk world you inhabit. Snippets of the text dialogue could use some touching up, but information is communicated well and characterizations are done competently.Frozen Synapse is everything I want from a tactical game, in the sense of both gameplay and presentation. An absolute masterclass indie product!

Posted: June 1, 2013
												So... why haven't you bought this yet? This is a simultaneous turn based tactics game, not to mention an absolute delight to play! To describe this game in such a small space is difficult, which is a testament to just how in depth this experience can be using a perfectly simple interface. Sure the graphics might not be the bells and whistles of X-com, but you owe it to yourself to try this new breed of TBS/T.And even better? Extremely accessible multiplayer that provides the conveniance of an old school PBEM without all the annoyings bits - take turns when it suits you. Rugged coop and a decent single player campaign... not to mention a whole slew of tactical game types. When things get good its almost like you're playing a top down arena based shooter, and you'll cringe as each tiny faceless trooper gets popped off by your ruthless opponent.Let the arm chair commander within you be unleashed!

Posted: June 20, 2011
												I'm not very good at strategy games. Luckily for me, there's Frozen Synapse, a squad-based tactical game that's one of the most addictive indie titles I've played all year. The style of FS is quite nice, with a quasi-cyberpunk setting, a simplistic graphic style that recalls Metal Gear Solid's VR missions and an electronic soundtrack that's pretty impressive in its own right. Matches can be lightning fast or last days a la chess. Such is the beauty of the turn-based gameplay in FS. The multiplayer community is robust as of this review, and I get plenty of invites whether I'm playing single player or multiplayer. The multiplayer community is great. In the few matches I've played (and lost), competitors have never hesitated to give me tips on strategy. Community aside, there some great features, such as "light" and "dark" modes (which determine fog of war) as well as instant Youtube uploads, giving you plenty of reference for strategy and a way to showcase your wins

This is one game that really needs it, especially with Steam's potential plans to make its games available on Tablets. With data backed up onto the cloud, you'd be able to play at home or on the go without much hassle. This is not possible.

Posted: April 30, 2014
												Being a fan of tactical shooters, I'd picked up Frozen Synapse the second I'd heard of it. I'd gone in expecting the same levels of awesomeness I'd experienced in titles such as Ghost Recon and Rainbow Six.I wasn't disappointed.As I'm sure you've gathered by now, Frozen Synapse is a turn-based strategy game. Both teams piece together their plans, press the start button, and watch as the battle unfolds. The planning phase makes up the vast majority of the game, with most of your time spent fiddling with aiming directions, movement, testing the layout of your troops against every possible scenario and so on and so forth. It takes an incredible amount of time to plan out a turn that effectively lasts five seconds- but you'd better believe that they're some of the tensest five seconds I've ever experienced in gaming. Beyond its brilliant core gameplay, Frozen Synapse boasts an intriguing storyline and setting that's vague in all the right places along with an absolutely fantastic soundtrack. I'd fully recommend this to anybody with a love for tactical squad based combat and strategy. It's a great game.

Posted: April 18, 2014
												I really thought I liked these types of games.  I enjoyed "Breach and Clear" so I thought I would also enjoy Frozen Synapse.  While the background elements are fine (helps explain the plain graphics), the micro-managing is a LOT more intense (that is, there was basically no micro-managing in Breach & Clear).  This is pretty cool.  Also, the AI is much more advanced, which is good training for multi-player (to a degree).  Where B&C was a simple single-player game, Frozen Synapse really shines in multi-player.  In fact, I'd recommend it for fans of the tactical/turn-based genre who solely like multiplayer.  For casual, single players, you might like it - but the campaign got frustrating really fast for me.  Sometimes my guys would not move at all and get picked off; the cpu could not only peg me from afar with an automatic weapon, but also turn and kill the guy who flanked him and was behind cover... nice.  For the CPU.  Several "turns" I was like, "really?  REALLY?  Sure."  That kind of frustration.But hey, in the end, it's all about polishing one's tactics and learning your opponent (whether they're a CPU or a human).  For the sale price (and linux support) it was a no-brainer to buy (and you do get two copies, since it is so multi-player, 1-on-1 heavy).  An excellent buy and incredible value.

Posted: June 23, 2014
												This'll be a short review because I got a lot of turns pending :DFrozen Synapse is a turn-based strategy-game similar to Breach&Clear but with a more intense focus on multiplayer.Overview:The game is set in a future world in the city Markov Geist. The reality has become divided into the real world, controlled by humans, and the shape, something like a second reality that can be accessed through the widespread wireless network that has been established over the years. It's home of so called shapeforms which I won't explain in detail.The setting is somewhat similar to that of the Shadowrun Universe (Cyberpunk).Gameplay:As there are so many other reviewers out there who already explained the gameplay in detail, I will just sum up my impressions. The game easy to learn but hard as f*** to master. You are given a small tutorial which explains the basic commands and teaches you how to chain them and plan your turn. Then you're on your own to figure out what to do with that information. I suggest playing the campaign a little before jumping into multiplayer.The mechanics are fair although sometimes frustrating since who kills who depends on a list of factors you have to be aware of and at times they are not that easy to assess. But that's what makes this game great. It really forces you to THINK about what to do next!The graphics speak for themselves. Simple yet stylish. You get a good overview of the map and there are no irrelevant objects. If you can see it, it has a function -> Good guys, bad guys, cover, walls. That's it.Summing up I did not regret paying 7€ for this. If you also want to play Coop, buy the Red DLC. Only one of the Coop-Players needs it for coop to work which I think is really well done!

Posted: February 28, 2014
												Simple, yet chess like in its replayabiltiy, Frozen Synapse is a turn based tactical combat game.  You control a fix number of solders armed, each with a specific weapon.  Load out varies per map and round, but they navigate a simple techno/hologramed terrain with walls and windows, in an attempt to take out the other guy.  Turns are not executed live, so you can have a slow play game with someone, simply putting in your turn when you have time, or you can be running multiple games at once.  Once your turn is submitted, your opponent gets a message and vise-versa, at which point you can view the results of that round and plan your next.Turns are process simultaneously so you setup your mans with postures, positions and what direction their facing.  As you move around the small map, so does the other guy, when your mans see someone, they shoot (unless told not to).  It's satisfying and frustrating to see each round unfold and it's immensely challenging to attempt to get your mans into the best position to attack the other guy.Take that simple gameplay mechanic and throw in a couple classic game modes like King of the Hill and recue/protect the hostages and an additional mode called charge where you bid on how far you believe you can get and hold a position on the map.  Each play puts their bid in at the beginning of the game and whoever is more aggressive (distance from starting point) in their bid wins the bid and must then achieve that position.Each round is unique and challenge.  While there's AI to train yourself on (which scales well) the match making system is where it's at.  Stat tracking and ranking is very much a part of the game and it ends up pairing you for battles that don't tend to feel lopsided.It's a small, simple game so despite being really good I'll say it's worth $10.  Add another $3 to throw it on android and you can process those turns on the go.  Worth it.Visuals 6Gamplay 8Slant 7Overall : 70

Posted: January 10, 2014
												This thing is raw stategy. You have a squad of "vatforms," essentially clones into which orders can be plugged. You must provide those orders in this turn-based squad combat game. Except it doesn't feel so turn based, because after each planning phase where you meticulously plotted routes and arcs of fire for your units, all the action hashes out in real time.The game basically does a bunch of behind the scenes math to come up with the result, taking into account cover, movement, range, wepon type, etc. After a bit, you catch on to the basic rules of who's going to survive a given one on one encounter, and you can start testing strategies by running real time simulations of enemy movements (with orders given by you based on what you think they might do) before you submit each turn.Add to the rock solid core mechanics a compelling story, holographic computer simulation graphics style, and awesome soundtrack, and you have top notch game.Did I mention there's procedurally generated maps and multiplayer?

Posted: July 29, 2011
												Frozen Synapse... this game is rather hard to classify. It's a turn based simulation of turn-based combat. It runs by a few simple rules, yet it's random and at the same time, calculative nature keeps it much more complicated. It can be as simple as a game of chess, or as complicated as political usurpation. The gameplay holds quite well to both those who enjoy full control of the situation and those who preffer to let things play out by themselves.The campaign takes you on an interesting trip through futuristic city of Markov Geist. You are aided by a number of characters such as idealistic Nix, snide Belacqua, and caring Soulsby. Although the campaign can be difficult at times, it is ultimately enjoyable, and beating a mission has a sense of achievement. The strange nature of the game's AI however, can be a problem at times.Multiplayer on the other hand, features great implementation of communications and planing. It is the main reason that this game should be acquiered.

Posted: May 27, 2011
												Frozen Synapse has been described as “Chess with Guns” but this does little to communicate the fantastic cyberpunk theme the pervades the experience. The score pulses through the experience spurring you on as you plan your next move, running simulation after simulation, attempting to find a way to evade that rocket that was fired a turn earlier. Posted: January 9, 2014
												Although it may look a little lack lustre, Frozen Synapse is in fact a very deep turn-based strategy in the vein of XCOM or Heroes of Might & Magic with a twist: once you and your opponent decide your units' moves, it becomes a real-time action sequence and your strategy goes against theirs. The story became gripping and the characters very interesting. It's a mix of corporate espionage, rebellion, and a war of beliefs coming together to make a fantastic singleplayer.On the multiplayer side, it comes with the added benefit of being asynchronous (after you setup your strategy, you can wander off for hours while your opponent decides; kind of like chess by mail). The game modes are neat and varied and seting up a match is pretty easy. Another plus, the people I played against were gratious and felt like a great community.Finally, after listening to the trailers, I decided to buy the soundtrack, and boy was it worth it! Still in my play list today.

Posted: May 29, 2014
												SummaryIn short, Frozen Synapse is a turn based counter strike with focus on tactics rather than action in a cyper-punk setting.You get thrown right into the action from your first match with little introduction which may put off some people. I did not find it too bad though.When playing against other players online, it feels very rewarding to win a match. Seeing a carefully planned out plan work feels great! However losing also feels as progress as you gain experience points for your actions rather then just the outcome.GameplayYou control a team of units armed with different weapons (either shotgun, grenade, machine-gun, sniper or rocket) in a battlefield against opponent units. Orders are given to a single unit as a path of nodes to travel along and you can assign actions along the path such as "crouch", "ignore at sight",  "shoot at sight", "wait" and "look in this direction". You can order units to take cover, make distractions, flank enemies, flush out enemies and many other tactics that make use of the randomly generated environment. You can also simulate the enemy units to test out your plans and make sure you covered all outcomes. It is hard to describe the feeling of seing enemies fall into your traps or pressured into defeat other than "Just as planned...".The game was slightly intimidating in the beginning as there are many things to get used to and most of it is presented without much introduction. There is a single player campaign which presents all actions from the first mission and the tutorial only teaches a few basic tactics. Generally the overall focus seemed to be on playing online and learning by doing and failing.Multi-playerOnline works overall well. You can play any number of matches you want at once as the game does not progress until both players have submitted your plans. Once both players have submitted their plans, the outcome is played out. You can also choose to have the game notify you by email or through Steam when your next turn is ready.ThemeLastly I really like the overall style of the game. The music is very fitting and the sparse visuals keeps focus on the gameplay.

I highly recommend this game.

												So... why haven't you bought this yet? This is a simultaneous turn based tactics game, not to mention an absolute delight to play! To describe this game in such a small space is difficult, which is a testament to just how in depth this experience can be using a perfectly simple interface. Sure the graphics might not be the bells and whistles of X-com, but you owe it to yourself to try this new breed of TBS/T.And even better? Extremely accessible multiplayer that provides the conveniance of an old school PBEM without all the annoyings bits - take turns when it suits you. Rugged coop and a decent single player campaign... not to mention a whole slew of tactical game types. When things get good its almost like you're playing a top down arena based shooter, and you'll cringe as each tiny faceless trooper gets popped off by your ruthless opponent.Let the arm chair commander within you be unleashed!

Posted: January 3, 2012
												This is a great little strategy game. I got it for free in the Great Gift Pile during the 2011 holiday sale (thanks, Valve!), and must say I was pleasantly surprised by how much fun it is.I've barely touched the campaign, mostly because "Instant skirmish" is fun enough.There's a room with around 3-6 enemies and a squad of friendly soldiers you can map out the paths for and set their stance/aiming/targeting options. Once you've done this, you click the "prime" button, and your sequence of moves plays out at the same time as the AI's. The process repeats until everyone on one team is dead. Simple, right?The key phrase for Frozen Synapse is "just one more game". The skirmishes are nice and short, and the gameplay is simple and addictive. Be prepared to start playing one morning, then quit playing and find that the authorities have declared you legally dead.Overall, a solid strategy game and a great time-waster. And I've barely scratched the surface here.

Posted: December 20, 2011
Worth it for the soundtrack alone, which is mind-blowing imho.The game itself is Turn-based and it' s easy to pick up but hard to master. The UI allows you to customise your every command up to the tiniest level of detail.The game offers a campaign but it really shines when playing against a human opponent, when you try to get into the mind of your adversery and anticipate his next move. The multiplayer part of the game is very well made and it supports many features that embellish it, like a replay system, a matchmaking system where you can be randomly challenged by individuals into 1 vs 1 duels, a pause/resume online game feature where the online mode is put on hold until both parties agree to continue, match notification by e-mail, leaderboards, match spectation, etc.There is also a skirmish level generator where you can create your own scenarios against diffirent styles of AI (aggressive, defensive, etc). Highly recommended if you're into mind games.

Posted: May 28, 2011
												Frozen Synapse  is a rather excellent strategy game that blends a minimalist style with intricate tactics. Players control squads of soldiers, and plan out their exact movements down to the last second. There is none of that "click and go" style crap here; in order to succeed, you must carefully weave your squad around corners with synchronous precision, divert sight lines towards choke points, and above all, predict where your opponent will be. Also, Introversion fans may be surprised to find that Frozen Synapse, is, in fact, not created by Introversion, but rather mode7 games. They could have fooled me- FS's style is no less slick than Introversion's best.

Posted: July 6, 2011
												In a market over-saturated with instant-satisfaction run-and-gun shooters, there has been a lingering void of video games that focus heavily on tactical decision-making, deception and patience. Frozen Synapse not only fills this void but also offers gameplay that remains and will remain addictive and satisfying for years to come. What makes this turn-based, strategic game extremely gratifying is the ability to not only issue complex multi-layered orders to each of your own individual units but also the ability to issue the same extent of orders to the units of your opponent — providing the capability to explore and simulate how you might expect your opponent to carry out his or her next move. Regardless of whether or not your opponent reacts in the way you might have prognosticated, the anticipation to see the outcome of the next move can at times be overwhelmingly exhilarating. This coupled with an exceptional soundtrack and visuals is indicative of how excellent indie games can be.

Posted: December 27, 2011
												Quite an interesting and unique spin on turn based strategy games.  The game is fairly simple and straightforward, but planning out moves can take a while (if you get really in depth).  You don't even have to be around for the entire match, and can log back on at intervals in order to plan out turns over time.  I've enjoyed this game so far, though I will admit, it occasionally doesn't seem to follow its own rules and my characters seem to die in situations that they shouldn't.

Posted: July 4, 2011
												Do you like to play chess? Do you get satisfaction from destroying your opponents carefully laid plans with one swift move? We all do, don't we? And most of us have, in one time or another, sat for tedious hours planning entry points and drawing target lines in Rainbow Six (the original ones, mind you) or Jagged Alliance and gotten major kicks when these crazy plans actually worked. If you are one of us, then here's an order: get Frozen Synapse. It may resemble an 80's game, but trust me, it's a 100% pure strategy and psychology. You thought you could figure out what your opponent will do next? Think again! This is chess..with guns!

Posted: April 30, 2014
												Being a fan of tactical shooters, I'd picked up Frozen Synapse the second I'd heard of it. I'd gone in expecting the same levels of awesomeness I'd experienced in titles such as Ghost Recon and Rainbow Six.I wasn't disappointed.As I'm sure you've gathered by now, Frozen Synapse is a turn-based strategy game. Both teams piece together their plans, press the start button, and watch as the battle unfolds. The planning phase makes up the vast majority of the game, with most of your time spent fiddling with aiming directions, movement, testing the layout of your troops against every possible scenario and so on and so forth. It takes an incredible amount of time to plan out a turn that effectively lasts five seconds- but you'd better believe that they're some of the tensest five seconds I've ever experienced in gaming. Beyond its brilliant core gameplay, Frozen Synapse boasts an intriguing storyline and setting that's vague in all the right places along with an absolutely fantastic soundtrack. I'd fully recommend this to anybody with a love for tactical squad based combat and strategy. It's a great game.

												Reminds me of some of the classic old-school games I played on my Apple 2! Great turn-based tactical squad shooter. Feels a bit like a puzzle game in some ways. Random map generation suggests that it's very replayable.You can compare it somewhat to an RTS in that you have multiple units to co-ordinate, but if you've ever wanted an RTS to be less frenetic and more focused on precision tactics, you'll probably enjoy this game.

Posted: May 28, 2011
												I was initially put off by what looked like a complicated micro-management game, but the interface turned out to be extremely intuitive. Run through the brief tutorial and you'll have the hang of it. This is not a game of attrition, one unit with good tactics can take down many more. It's chess with guns and no board. You get a couple of unit types in a turn-based tactical strategy game. If you don't plan well, you lose. The gameplay is easily addictive and the soundtrack makes it all worth the price.

Posted: August 7, 2011
												A must get for Strategy gamers; not only is it mind-numbingly difficult, but it forces you to think ahead of your opponent in order to outwit them. Every turn, the decisions that you AND your opponent play out simulataneously during the action phase. In turn, every time your finger hovers over the "Prime" button that locks in the moves you have made, you pray that the decisions you have made get you closer to victory and that you haven't sent your entire team to their deaths. Although unseen there will be much teeth grinding as you or your opponent lose a useful unit.Elegant, Difficult, Fun,Frozen Synapse is a Must Get8.7/10

Posted: January 10, 2015
												Don't get fooled by the bad (almost non-existant) graphics. If you like turn-based tactical games, this game is definitely one of the best I've tried. It differs from other turn-based games in that this one has simultaneous turns, which means each side chooses its moves and then both are resolved at the same time. It's like pausing the game, selecting what your men should do, then unpausing, with the difference that you cannot pause again until the turn is finished, so if you screwed up, you can just watch your team die. This means you have to somehow "guess" what your opponent is going to do, which is not always obvious./The gameplay is very good, with some options I only saw in this game, like waiting time and ignore enemies (the first 2 that pop in my head). Planning path and actions for your team is easy, but sometimes the paths overlap and it's a bit confusing in my opinion.The difficulty curve for single player is ok, introducing the different classes in a good pace and allowing you to understand their pros and cons.8/10

Posted: May 28, 2011
												I was initially put off by what looked like a complicated micro-management game, but the interface turned out to be extremely intuitive. Run through the brief tutorial and you'll have the hang of it. This is not a game of attrition, one unit with good tactics can take down many more. It's chess with guns and no board. You get a couple of unit types in a turn-based tactical strategy game. If you don't plan well, you lose. The gameplay is easily addictive and the soundtrack makes it all worth the price.

Posted: January 7, 2012
												A clever game with enough story to keep you going. You control a team of people with different weapons, and gameplay is turnbased. The aim is to destroy the other team, or perhaps to survive a number of levels without being destroyed, It varies from level to level. The game has its frustrating moments when it is probably a little harder than it needs to be. The tutorial also gets a little tedious. But for what it is, its not a bad little game.

Posted: October 4, 2011
												This is such a fun game. Quick to learn, and yet tons of endless strategy and fun. I've never played a game like it, and I totally love it. Get it! I've never come across a similar game, and if there are some, I would love to know about them.In Frozen Synapse, you have an endless variety of randomly generated maps to do battle on.You go through the planning phase, testing out tactics, giving your guys waypoints, telling them where to look, what enemies to engage or ignore. You can even give the enemy characters waypoints and instructions to test out what your enemy might do, or see if they get the drop on you if you make a certain move. You can try to anticipate their moves and make a bold decision that may backfire, or win you the game.After you've planned your turn you submit it, and it cannot be edited. When you and your opponent have both submitted, you see how your plans play out, for 5 seconds of action. (you can change the game length, but that's standard) You see what happened, then go back into the planning phase to play your next 5 seconds of action.There's a handful of game types and playmodes. My favorite is "dark extermination," where your objective is to wipe out your opponents players, and, after the start, once you lose line of sight on a character, you no longer know where they are. You just see a ghost of where they were, and how many seconds since you saw them last, so you can use their ghost in the planning phase, and if you're right about where it is, you can test out some tactics for it, and against it, and see hat your options are, but you might be wrong about where it is.This is one of my all time favorite Steam games and it has a lot of replayability, because it's always a different game. Especially when you start building custom battles by choosing how many characters you get and of which classes, to make custom games.One last thing I'll mention, and I think it's a brilliant aspect of the game: You can have multiple games going with different people at the same time, and just switch back and forth. You'll get notifications when someone in a different game has submitted their turn. Often times people will play games in a reasonable amount of time, but sometimes someone will leave before the game finishes, and you'll find that hours later, or the next day, they submitted a new turn. It's not uncommon to have some games that end up playing out over the course of a day or 2. If someone abandons the game because they're losing, after a few days the game will be closed and you'll get the win on your stats.

Posted: July 4, 2011
												Frozen Synapse will make your head hurt, possibly in a good way. It's Flotilla with foot soldiers. You have a squad of guys who follow your orders to the letter; so does your enemy. The trick is you give orders in phases, and both sides execute their orders in real time. Ordered your men to walk up behind an enemy and blast him? Too bad, your enemy ordered that guy to turn around moments before you arrive.It's pure tactics with no chance or twitch gaming in the way. Each battle is mathmatically solvable (To the point that you can simulate fights before you commit to your moves), there's no element of random here. It's a hard concept to wrap your head around, and you'll probably lose even the first single player mission many times before you get it, but once you do, there's multiple game modes, multiplayer, and an engrossing campaign to keep you hooked.

												Quite an interesting and unique spin on turn based strategy games.  The game is fairly simple and straightforward, but planning out moves can take a while (if you get really in depth).  You don't even have to be around for the entire match, and can log back on at intervals in order to plan out turns over time.  I've enjoyed this game so far, though I will admit, it occasionally doesn't seem to follow its own rules and my characters seem to die in situations that they shouldn't.

Posted: July 4, 2011
												Do you like to play chess? Do you get satisfaction from destroying your opponents carefully laid plans with one swift move? We all do, don't we? And most of us have, in one time or another, sat for tedious hours planning entry points and drawing target lines in Rainbow Six (the original ones, mind you) or Jagged Alliance and gotten major kicks when these crazy plans actually worked. If you are one of us, then here's an order: get Frozen Synapse. It may resemble an 80's game, but trust me, it's a 100% pure strategy and psychology. You thought you could figure out what your opponent will do next? Think again! This is chess..with guns!

Posted: April 18, 2014
												I really thought I liked these types of games.  I enjoyed "Breach and Clear" so I thought I would also enjoy Frozen Synapse.  While the background elements are fine (helps explain the plain graphics), the micro-managing is a LOT more intense (that is, there was basically no micro-managing in Breach & Clear).  This is pretty cool.  Also, the AI is much more advanced, which is good training for multi-player (to a degree).  Where B&C was a simple single-player game, Frozen Synapse really shines in multi-player.  In fact, I'd recommend it for fans of the tactical/turn-based genre who solely like multiplayer.  For casual, single players, you might like it - but the campaign got frustrating really fast for me.  Sometimes my guys would not move at all and get picked off; the cpu could not only peg me from afar with an automatic weapon, but also turn and kill the guy who flanked him and was behind cover... nice.  For the CPU.  Several "turns" I was like, "really?  REALLY?  Sure."  That kind of frustration.But hey, in the end, it's all about polishing one's tactics and learning your opponent (whether they're a CPU or a human).  For the sale price (and linux support) it was a no-brainer to buy (and you do get two copies, since it is so multi-player, 1-on-1 heavy).  An excellent buy and incredible value.

Posted: December 6, 2014
												To say it in short: I love this game! To say a bit more: It is a tactical turn based game where the turns are prepared simultaneously by the players. This game can be played online and offline, against the AI in skirmish mode or in a campaign as well as against other players from around the world. It can be nailbiting while you watch the outcome and realize all your awesome and unbeatable planning goes down the toilet as your opponent does exactly what you didn't think of. And on the other hand, the feeling is great when you watch your plan unfold and you stomp the opponent into the ground. But the best thing is, if things go awry and you lose, you always know it had nothing to do with luck but all with the mistakes you did. It is a bit like chess where you have to plan your moves into the future and adapt to the strategies of your opponent. The units you (can) use range from machinegunners, to shotguns, rocket launcher and grenades to snipers and riot shilds. There are also differnt types of scenarios such as rescue hostages, secure a specific area or just plain extermination to name only a few. The most important thing about this game is that you cannot just rush in and shoot blindly. You have to use a tactical approach and plan your moves carefully. Your units don't have many hitpoints as in classical shooters. One hit and they are dead biomass. Buildings and covers can be destroyed by rockets. So depending on the units there might be not a save spot to just sit and wait. Another nice aspect of this game is, that you don't need to be permanently online. You can plan your moves offline. And soon as the turn result is there, you get notified of it and can prepare the next turn. So even for casual players who don't have much time, this is a good game to spend a few minutes for your turn and upload it. I really hope this game gets more attention as it surly deserves it. The grafics in Tron style and the nice soundtrack are really catchy. Very nice is also, that when you buy a game, you also get a second one to send to a friend. So would i recommend the game? Yes, definitely!

												Calm and calculating. With realistic combat, every unit matters, and the tense gameplay cannot be matched anywhere else. This is highly recommended to any fans of strategy games, especially turn-based.9 out of 10 - Nico

Posted: April 20, 2014
												Something to understand before playing this game: its not a game for the masses. It's not an extreamly popular genre, it has confusing controls, and one might even say that it has qwerky mechanics. But its a game unlike anything you've ever played before. Asyncronous Turn-Based Strategy. A brilliant idea, but where it excedes in Frozen Synapse is in the execution. This game could be reviewed by an unenlightened gamer as an "annoying, confusing, turn-based strategy game", but what it actually does is it makes you think. And then it makes you think again. And again. In the words of Sun Tzu:“To know your Enemy, you must become your Enemy.”You must think like your enemy. You must find every possible senerio and make a counter for each, or take a risk, and prepare for the most likely one. All the while knowing that your enemy is thinking just like you. It require a mental skillset that not only do most gamers not want to have to use, but do not have at all. However, if you think you have what it takes, and you think that you are able to not just think for yourself, but think for your enemy, and plan ten steps ahead, then this just may be the game you've been waiting for.

Posted: April 20, 2014
												An excellent deterministic game (no luck involved) at its core with different units that have strengths and weaknesses. I find it works in principle very similar to chess, another deterministic game without luck involved. Although this game has the advantage from a pure principle perspective in that there is no first move advantage; both players execute their moves simultaneously.Randomized maps can give one person an unlucky starting situation though, however I find that adds to the fun and keeps the game fresh. It also proves skill; its easy to memorize maps and with enough play through with different people, get an intuitive feel for what is common and what is not, and play accordingly. But with new maps generated and starting positions semi-random, it can really determine between two players who actually has adaptive skill, and who perhaps does not.I would recommend this game especially on discount for anyone who enjoys strategy/tactical games.

So even for casual players who don't have much time, this is a good game to spend a few minutes for your turn and upload it. I really hope this game gets more attention as it surly deserves it. The grafics in Tron style and the nice soundtrack are really catchy. Very nice is also, that when you buy a game, you also get a second one to send to a friend. So would i recommend the game? Yes, definitely!

Posted: April 30, 2014
												Being a fan of tactical shooters, I'd picked up Frozen Synapse the second I'd heard of it. I'd gone in expecting the same levels of awesomeness I'd experienced in titles such as Ghost Recon and Rainbow Six.I wasn't disappointed.As I'm sure you've gathered by now, Frozen Synapse is a turn-based strategy game. Both teams piece together their plans, press the start button, and watch as the battle unfolds. The planning phase makes up the vast majority of the game, with most of your time spent fiddling with aiming directions, movement, testing the layout of your troops against every possible scenario and so on and so forth. It takes an incredible amount of time to plan out a turn that effectively lasts five seconds- but you'd better believe that they're some of the tensest five seconds I've ever experienced in gaming. Beyond its brilliant core gameplay, Frozen Synapse boasts an intriguing storyline and setting that's vague in all the right places along with an absolutely fantastic soundtrack. I'd fully recommend this to anybody with a love for tactical squad based combat and strategy. It's a great game.

Posted: June 23, 2014
												This'll be a short review because I got a lot of turns pending :DFrozen Synapse is a turn-based strategy-game similar to Breach&Clear but with a more intense focus on multiplayer.Overview:The game is set in a future world in the city Markov Geist. The reality has become divided into the real world, controlled by humans, and the shape, something like a second reality that can be accessed through the widespread wireless network that has been established over the years. It's home of so called shapeforms which I won't explain in detail.The setting is somewhat similar to that of the Shadowrun Universe (Cyberpunk).Gameplay:As there are so many other reviewers out there who already explained the gameplay in detail, I will just sum up my impressions. The game easy to learn but hard as f*** to master. You are given a small tutorial which explains the basic commands and teaches you how to chain them and plan your turn. Then you're on your own to figure out what to do with that information. I suggest playing the campaign a little before jumping into multiplayer.The mechanics are fair although sometimes frustrating since who kills who depends on a list of factors you have to be aware of and at times they are not that easy to assess. But that's what makes this game great. It really forces you to THINK about what to do next!The graphics speak for themselves. Simple yet stylish. You get a good overview of the map and there are no irrelevant objects. If you can see it, it has a function -> Good guys, bad guys, cover, walls. That's it.Summing up I did not regret paying 7€ for this. If you also want to play Coop, buy the Red DLC. Only one of the Coop-Players needs it for coop to work which I think is really well done!

Posted: September 25, 2014
												This is my first time reviewing a game on Steam, but I think this is the right game to review as I enjoy it so much. I was first exposed to this game through the iPad. I was looking around online for a competitive turn-based strategy game, one that would be fast-paced yet satisfying. Different names came up across the Web, but Frozen Synapse was consistently showing up throughout forums and blogs. I decided to give it a go.At first, being that it was my first time ever being exposed to a simultaneous TBS, it took a little getting used to the concept. But that was accomplished after the first mission in the campaign. The trickier parts are predicting who wins a gun-fight in a given scenario and understanding all the orders you can give and when. These come with continuous exposure and practice.The game definitely requires strategy and good planning, but it also allows for randomness to affect a match at times, such as when neither you nor your opponent know where the other is. The learning curve isn't anywhere near as steep as for other strategy or tactical games, which means you'll probably get the hang of it after the first couple of missions in campaign or matches online. Because each round online lasts a few seconds, you don't have to worry about wasting action points (there are none), rather, you get freedom to give as many orders to your units as you feel necessary to keep them safe and to ensure they are always in an advantageous position. And because there are only a few units in the game and you don't really need to worry about stats, everyone knows what to expect from the enemy in terms of units and capabilities.The campaign mode seems legit. I played about 7 missions perhaps, give or take, and they vary from simple to challenging. The online mode, though, is where it's at. There are many game modes in online, from a simple team death match to hostage rescuing scenarios. It seems there's always someone to play against, and you and the other player can decide how fast-paced the game should be. I once played a match that lasted only a few minutes when we were both online and another time I matched with someone and we took almost a week to finish the match. You get notifications when it's your turn to make a move. And you can start a match on your iPad and finish it on your computer or vice versa. The only downside is that your progress on your PC or iPad for the campaign stays put - that doesn't transfer.To summarize, the game is easy to get into, very addictive, requires strategy but leaves a little room for luck, has an excellent multiplayer system with diverse scenarios/modes, the gameplay can be rather fast, and it allows you to play between devices. Obviously I recommend this game to anyone who is even slightly inclined to tactical sorts of games.

Posted: January 9, 2014
												Although it may look a little lack lustre, Frozen Synapse is in fact a very deep turn-based strategy in the vein of XCOM or Heroes of Might & Magic with a twist: once you and your opponent decide your units' moves, it becomes a real-time action sequence and your strategy goes against theirs. The story became gripping and the characters very interesting. It's a mix of corporate espionage, rebellion, and a war of beliefs coming together to make a fantastic singleplayer.On the multiplayer side, it comes with the added benefit of being asynchronous (after you setup your strategy, you can wander off for hours while your opponent decides; kind of like chess by mail). The game modes are neat and varied and seting up a match is pretty easy. Another plus, the people I played against were gratious and felt like a great community.Finally, after listening to the trailers, I decided to buy the soundtrack, and boy was it worth it! Still in my play list today.

Posted: January 10, 2014
												This thing is raw stategy. You have a squad of "vatforms," essentially clones into which orders can be plugged. You must provide those orders in this turn-based squad combat game. Except it doesn't feel so turn based, because after each planning phase where you meticulously plotted routes and arcs of fire for your units, all the action hashes out in real time.The game basically does a bunch of behind the scenes math to come up with the result, taking into account cover, movement, range, wepon type, etc. After a bit, you catch on to the basic rules of who's going to survive a given one on one encounter, and you can start testing strategies by running real time simulations of enemy movements (with orders given by you based on what you think they might do) before you submit each turn.Add to the rock solid core mechanics a compelling story, holographic computer simulation graphics style, and awesome soundtrack, and you have top notch game.Did I mention there's procedurally generated maps and multiplayer?

Posted: October 29, 2016
												It is hard to fit this game into a Genre. Obviously it is a strategy game, and it has turns, but it is not a turn-based strategy game per se. You see, Turn based Strategy like XCOM or Civilization often rely on the simple scheme of Player A, then Player B, then Player A etc. Frozen Synapse however takes a unique approach on it: Both Players at the same time. Each turn takes 5 seconds where each player has to plan the movements of their units - at the same time. Once both players are happy with what their units are going to do they hit the "Prime" button, and the scenario is played out. At this stage there is nothing the player can do to inflcuence the outcome. You can't command your units and have to watch as they win or loose, based on what you told them to do. This concept might sound weird at first but it allows for very balanced gameplay as no player has an advantage. You as the player are just a camera from above commanding the units, waiting for them to fulfull their orders. It allows for a higher strategial depth, a 5 second turn can take 5+ minutes to figure out. The game provides a "simluation" button, where youc an preview what your units will do. You can, at the same time, give the enemy units commands for the purpose of simulating to test your scenario. It is easy to get lost in the amount of tinkering you need to do, and you never know what is going to happen. Overall this game is game is great, it offers a great breath of fresh air into the genre of strategy games. I would suggest waiting for Frozen Synpase 2, as it will release in "Late 2016". It looks like this game and probably playes like it as well. If you can't wait or just want a great game in your library buy this.

												Unlike XCOM and other turn-based strategies, where the main resource are factors like:cover, character states and generally chance.This game manages to remove the "chance" aspect and replace it with "time".Everything from turns to killing an opposing unit requires time. There is no chance, there is no blind luck, there are no 95% chance to hit *аnd then miss* moments, there is no RNGesus, there is none of that ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t.This makes gameplay a lot less frustrating, more predictable and overall, more enjoyable.

Posted: July 6, 2011
												In a market over-saturated with instant-satisfaction run-and-gun shooters, there has been a lingering void of video games that focus heavily on tactical decision-making, deception and patience. Frozen Synapse not only fills this void but also offers gameplay that remains and will remain addictive and satisfying for years to come. What makes this turn-based, strategic game extremely gratifying is the ability to not only issue complex multi-layered orders to each of your own individual units but also the ability to issue the same extent of orders to the units of your opponent — providing the capability to explore and simulate how you might expect your opponent to carry out his or her next move. Regardless of whether or not your opponent reacts in the way you might have prognosticated, the anticipation to see the outcome of the next move can at times be overwhelmingly exhilarating. This coupled with an exceptional soundtrack and visuals is indicative of how excellent indie games can be.

Posted: June 24, 2014
												This game is just incredible. The design appears simple, but there's so much depth to the strategy that it becomes both addicting and hugely tense in short order. Anticipating enemy movements, adapting to contingencies, and determining the best way to use the forces at your disposal make the gameplay immensely rewarding. The simultaneous turn resolution throws in further decision-making concerns and makes strategy development that much more dynamic and exciting. The soundtrack is phenomenal, as well, and really helps to enhance the cyberpunk world you inhabit. Snippets of the text dialogue could use some touching up, but information is communicated well and characterizations are done competently.Frozen Synapse is everything I want from a tactical game, in the sense of both gameplay and presentation. An absolute masterclass indie product!

Posted: June 22, 2014
												I personally don't like shooter games, so Frozen Synapse was not a natural purchase for me. It came highly recommended, though, and I personally woudl say that I do not regret buying it. There's something very satisfying about this tactical strategy shooter: setting up a plan of attack, viewing its potential outcome and reviewing every single step of the attack process. When you see a well-planned attack go off perfectly with pinpoint precision, you come away feeling like a god.There's only one downside: there's no steam cloud backup of your data. This is one game that really needs it, especially with Steam's potential plans to make its games available on Tablets. With data backed up onto the cloud, you'd be able to play at home or on the go without much hassle. This is not possible.

Posted: March 19, 2016
												If you're a fan on turn-based strategy games, you have to play this. This game is unmatched. One of the best games of all time. You make a plan for your units, they make a plan for their units. Nothing happens until both plans _come together_ and you see how the moves stacked up against eachother. Each turn spans a 5 second window of time. You see what happens and then you make another move to cover another 5 seconds of the action.There are a good amount of modes and plenty of unit types to keep things fresh and exciting. It has a few bugs/flaws and a lot of untapped potential (they're making a sequel!!), but never gets old.8.5/10

Posted: July 4, 2011
												Frozen Synapse will make your head hurt, possibly in a good way. It's Flotilla with foot soldiers. You have a squad of guys who follow your orders to the letter; so does your enemy. The trick is you give orders in phases, and both sides execute their orders in real time. Ordered your men to walk up behind an enemy and blast him? Too bad, your enemy ordered that guy to turn around moments before you arrive.It's pure tactics with no chance or twitch gaming in the way. Each battle is mathmatically solvable (To the point that you can simulate fights before you commit to your moves), there's no element of random here. It's a hard concept to wrap your head around, and you'll probably lose even the first single player mission many times before you get it, but once you do, there's multiple game modes, multiplayer, and an engrossing campaign to keep you hooked.

Posted: July 4, 2011
												It's a turn-based strategy game that takes the "luck" aspect out by letting you run sims of what both your units and the enemy units do BEFORE confirming your turn. The fact that it comes in 2-packs is good, as well: it means that you can always play it with your friends. Speaking of which, the online is handled by e-mail: You get messaged when any current game you're in is ready for you. Basically, if you're a fan of strategy games, this should not be missed.Now if you'll excuse me, I need to re-strategise my next turn...

Posted: January 10, 2015
												Don't get fooled by the bad (almost non-existant) graphics. If you like turn-based tactical games, this game is definitely one of the best I've tried. It differs from other turn-based games in that this one has simultaneous turns, which means each side chooses its moves and then both are resolved at the same time. It's like pausing the game, selecting what your men should do, then unpausing, with the difference that you cannot pause again until the turn is finished, so if you screwed up, you can just watch your team die. This means you have to somehow "guess" what your opponent is going to do, which is not always obvious./The gameplay is very good, with some options I only saw in this game, like waiting time and ignore enemies (the first 2 that pop in my head). Planning path and actions for your team is easy, but sometimes the paths overlap and it's a bit confusing in my opinion.The difficulty curve for single player is ok, introducing the different classes in a good pace and allowing you to understand their pros and cons.8/10

												This is a great game of tactics. Simultaneous order execution is the perfect implementation for this type of game. It also supports a play-by-email format, of sorts. Simply start a game and issue orders. Once your opponent has issued orders, the orders are resolved and the next turn becomes available for both players to log in, view the previous turn outcome and then issue orders anew. Really great game. Prime looks like a waste of time and money. FS2 looks like it could be a worthy successor.

Posted: December 23, 2011
												I'm absolutely astonished by this game. Agreed, the graphics are not much to look at, but the gameplay more than makes up for it. This is tactical excellence to the fullest.Basicly, you take full control of a squad of infiltrators, and have to eliminate the opposing force. Micromanagement is a must if you want to succeed in this game, and this makes the planning sequence of the game crucial to your success. Turns are in 5 second intervals that you have to plan out in advance, and not knowing what the enemy will do can have lethal consequences if you're sloppy in your planning.If you're impatient of nature, this is NOT a game for you, especially in multiplayer where waiting for the other player to finish the planning can be quite long.But if you like turn based strategy and tactics, the gameplay will keep you hooked for hours.IMPORTANT !Buying this game will grant you TWO copies of the game, so you can gift a copy to a friend, or trade it for something else with another user.
